title: Corrections: March 10, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 10, 2024.
content: An article last Sunday about the current tax season misstated the timing of required minimum with­drawals from tax­-advantaged retire­ment accounts for people who turned 73 in 2023. Their first with­drawal was due April 1, 2023 — and the second by Dec. 31, 2023; the deadline for their first withdrawal is not April 1, 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar, Raja Abdulrahim and Andrew Jacobs
title: Dispute Over Gaza War Heats Up Between Biden and Netanyahu
description: The Israeli prime minister rejected a rebuke from the U.S. president over the scale of the Israel assault.
content: A day after President Biden asserted that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was “hurting Israel more than helping Israel,” Mr. Netanyahu dismissed that contention as “wrong,” escalating the leaders’ increasingly public dispute.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Club Too Good to Be Ignored
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 10, 2024.
content: “I’ve never even been mentioned in the articles about the people who got snubbed. That’s a double snub!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: A Brooklyn Sex Club Promised Freedom. Some Called It Rape.
description: The leaders of Hacienda, perhaps New York City’s most prominent sex club, preach a gospel of continuous consent. Former members say when things went wrong, the group did not keep them safe.
content: The townhouse in Bushwick, Brooklyn, was once a beacon for Jennifer Fisher, a place where she did not have to hide that she was polyamorous and kinky, because her housemates were too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: As Israel’s Ties to Arab Countries Fray, a Strained Lifeline Remains
description: The United Arab Emirates has maintained its links to Israel throughout the war in Gaza, but the relationship, built on a U.S.-brokered deal, is under pressure as anger against Israel grows.
content: Only a few years ago, plenty of citizens of the United Arab Emirates were willing to speak warmly about their country’s budding ties with Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Fine, Call It a Comeback
description: The best line in Biden’s State of the Union was a surprise.
content: If the Joe Biden who showed up to deliver the State of the Union address last week is the Joe Biden who shows up for the rest of the campaign, you’re not going to have any more of those weak-kneed pundits suggesting he’s not up to running for re-election. Here’s hoping he does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Perlin
title: America Has No Official Language. Instead It Has Hundreds.
description: These languages and their speakers revitalize the profound social experiment that is America.
content: Nearly 400 years ago, Walloon-speaking religious refugees from near what is today roughly the French-Belgian border arrived in a Lenape-speaking archipelago, marking the colonial founding of Manhattan as we know it. Ever more global waves of migration have arrived since, enriching the city not just in practical ways, but also adding to its cultural and artistic texture. Today New York City is the most linguistically diverse urban area in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Feasts on the Bounty of the State of the Union
description: The Republican rebuttal delivered by Senator Katie Britt already struck many viewers as parody, making Scarlett Johansson’s job look easy.
content: It was inevitable that “Saturday Night Live” would sample heavily from the buffet of satirical potential offered by Thursday’s State of the Union. Perhaps the only question going into this weekend’s broadcast, hosted by Josh Brolin and featuring the musical guest Ariana Grande, was who would play Senator Katie Britt of Alabama, who delivered the much-discussed Republican response to President Biden’s speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Julia Roberts, Ice Spice, Robert De Niro and More Party Before the Oscars Even Start
description: Stars descend on the scene, and the biggest fashion brands in the world get into the action with as many events as people can possibly attend in one short weekend.
content: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Tung
title: ‘It’s a Way of Life’: Women Make Their Mark in the Ukrainian Army
description: As Ukraine struggles against Russian assaults and its losses mount, there has been a surge of women enlisting, and they are increasingly volunteering for combat roles.
content: On the front line just outside Bakhmut, Ukraine, a 32-year-old commander of a Ukrainian artillery platoon rocked to and fro in the passenger seat of a beat-up Lada, as another soldier navigated the car through a thick forest, sometimes mowing down young trees. When they reached their destination, a small village less than two miles from Russian lines, all that was left were destroyed houses, their shattered roofs visible in the moonlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: National Guard Can’t Carry Long Guns While Checking Bags in Subway
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul issued an order forbidding the weapons at bag-check stations on Wednesday, directly after her announcement that soldiers would be deployed to New York City’s subways.
content: Shortly after Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Wednesday that hundreds of National Guard soldiers would be deployed to patrol the New York City subway system and check riders’ bags, her office made an adjustment: Soldiers searching bags would not carry long guns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: The Coolest Menu Item at the Moment Is … Cabbage?
description: This stolid supporting player has slowly risen to a starring role in creative restaurants across the country. Some diners, though, may need a little coaxing.
content: If I were a vegetable, I would hire cabbage’s brand manager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Kathy Goldman, Who Fought Hunger in New York City, Dies at 92
description: She helped introduce free breakfasts and lunches for schoolchildren and open pantries and soup kitchens for the poor.
content: Kathy Goldman, who devoted her career as a civic leader to establishing food banks, pantries and free breakfast and lunch programs in public schools to sustain low-income New Yorkers, died on March 5 in Brooklyn. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: Oscars 2024 Winners: See the Full List
description: The complete list of winners for the 96th Academy Awards.
content: Read the highlights of the 2024 Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Hwaida Saad
title: Gaza Begins Ramadan With No Cease-Fire
description: There were hopes for a last-minute deal, but both sides said they weren’t close to an agreement.
content: International hopes at reaching a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip before the Muslim holy month of Ramadan were dashed on Sunday, hours before Palestinians and other Muslims were to begin the month of daytime fasting, as Hamas repeated demands for a comprehensive cease-fire, which Israel has rejected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Rich, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, Corey Schreppel and Brian St. Pierre
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Can Humans Endure the Psychological Torment of Mars?’
description: NASA is conducting tests on what might be the greatest challenge of a Mars mission: the trauma of isolation.
content: That people will travel to Mars, and soon, is a widely accepted conviction within NASA. Rachel McCauley, until recently the acting deputy director of NASA’s Mars campaign, had, as of July, a punch list of 800 problems that must be solved before the first human mission launches. Many of these concern the mechanical difficulties of transporting people to a planet that is never closer than 33.9 million miles away; keeping them alive on poisonous soil in unbreathable air, bombarded by solar radiation and galactic cosmic rays, without access to immediate communication; and returning them safely to Earth, more than a year and half later. But McCauley does not doubt that NASA will overcome these challenges. What NASA does not yet know — what nobody can know — is whether humanity can overcome the psychological torment of Martian life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Schiff Denies Porter’s Claim That the California Senate Primary Was Rigged
description: In an interview on NBC’s “Meet the Press,” Mr. Schiff pushed back on the assertion from one of his primary opponents that wealthy donors had spent millions of dollars to “rig” the race.
content: Representative Adam B. Schiff, who became the Democratic nominee for an open Senate seat in California last week, denied on Sunday the suggestion that his primary had been rigged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Pose Questions
description: How will you fare in this puzzle by Rebecca Goldstein and Rachel Fabi?
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria M. Walker
title: Brooklyn Scores With the First All-Electric Building in New York City
description: Alloy Development decided to keep gas appliances out of its new building, 505 State Street, for sustainability. The rule that would have required that move goes into effect in 2026.
content: In an ever-changing Downtown Brooklyn, high-rise apartment buildings nearing completion are a familiar sight. But there’s something a bit different about the one at 505 State Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Gimein
title: A Coming-of-Age Tale From the World of London High Finance
description: In “The Trading Game,” Gary Stevenson spills secrets of the City.
content: A coming-of-age story needs a love interest, a nemesis, a sturdy foundation of adversity and a generous seasoning of youthful rage and yearning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Klimt Landscape Show Is More, and Less, Than Expected
description: An engrossing exhibition at the Neue Galerie in Manhattan offers a small number of these fabled lush paintings but plenty of other treasures.
content: It was exciting to look forward to the exhibition “Klimt Landscapes,” now at the Neue Galerie. Klimt, of course, is Gustav Klimt (1862-1918), the Austrian modernist widely beloved for his paintings of the most beautiful women of Vienna’s haute bourgeoisie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: U.S. Military Ship Has Set Sail to Help Build Pier Off Gaza for Aid
description: The pier project is the latest in a flurry of efforts to get more aid into the enclave — including by sea — amid warnings from the U.N. that a famine in Gaza is imminent.
content: The U.S. military said on Sunday that a ship had set sail carrying equipment to build a floating pier on Gaza’s coast, part of a Biden administration effort to deliver aid to the enclave by sea and help ease its hunger crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky and Nathalia Angarita
title: Gabriel García Márquez’s Hometown Awaits His Last Book and More Visitors
description: The legacy of the global literary titan and Colombia’s most famous author has helped transform the small mountain town of Aracataca, where he was born.
content: Statues and murals bear his likeness. Schools and libraries are named after him. Hotels, barbershops, nightclubs and bike repair stores carry references to his work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: New York State Trooper Among Those Killed in Military Helicopter Crash
description: John M. Grassia III was one of three people killed when a National Guard helicopter crashed along the U.S.-Mexico border in Texas.
content: Two members of the New York State National Guard were identified as victims in a military helicopter crash that killed three people in Texas on Friday near the U.S.-Mexico border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Ryan Mac
title: Elon Musk Has a Giant Charity. Its Money Stays Close to Home.
description: After making billions in tax-deductible donations to his philanthropy, the owner of Tesla and SpaceX gave away far less than required in some years — and what he did give often supported his own interests.
content: Before March 2021, Elon Musk’s charitable foundation had never announced any donations to Cameron County, an impoverished region at the southern tip of Texas that is home to his SpaceX launch site and local officials who help regulate it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Paolo Taviani, Half of a Famed Italian Filmmaking Duo, Dies at 92
description: He and his brother Vittorio made films, including “Padre Padrone,” that mixed neorealism with a lyrical, almost magical sense of storytelling.
content: Paolo Taviani, who with his brother Vittorio made some of Italy’s most acclaimed films of the last half century — including “Padre Padrone,” which won the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in 1977 — died on Feb. 29 in Rome. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Palace Photo, Meant to Dispel Rumors About Catherine, Fans Them Instead
description: Kensington Palace released a Mother’s Day photo of Catherine, Princess of Wales, to showcase her health, but news agencies later said it had been manipulated.
content: A photograph of Catherine, Princess of Wales, with her three children, released by Kensington Palace and meant to showcase her recovery from surgery, has come under scrutiny after three news agencies advised news organizations on Sunday evening to withdraw it, saying the image had been manipulated by the palace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: A Sudden Turn in Voter Sentiment Helped Quash Changes to Ireland’s Constitution
description: The vote against the changes dealt a blow to a government that had hoped for an easy victory. But the outcome does not necessarily reflect a turn toward a more conservative electorate.
content: In early February, as a referendum approached that had been called by Ireland’s coalition government to consider two proposals to alter the country’s Constitution, polls showed that a clear majority of voters intended to support it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Amid Criticism, Britt Seeks to Defend Her Misleading Border Comments
description: Katie Britt, a Republican senator from Alabama, suggested on Fox News that viewers should have parsed her wording to determine that a sex-trafficking case she referred to wasn’t recent.
content: Senator Katie Britt of Alabama on Sunday sought to defend comments she made in her response to President Biden’s State of the Union address on Thursday, when she described the experience of a woman who was sexually trafficked in Mexico between 2004 and 2008 in a way that falsely implied it had happened in the United States under President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: About 63,000 Infant Swings Are Recalled Over Suffocation Hazard
description: Federal regulators said that the Jool Baby swings should not have been marketed as sleep products because they have an incline angle that is not safe.
content: Jool Baby, a brand of children’s products, has recalled about 63,000 infant swings that were sold at Walmart stores and online because they posed a suffocation risk, federal safety regulators said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: After Letitia James Wins Big in Courtrooms, She Celebrates in Public
description: Prevailing over former President Donald J. Trump and the National Rifle Association makes an elected Democrat a lightning rod. Foes call her vindictive. Allies say she’s just doing her job.
content: This has been a very good year for Letitia James.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Soll
title: There Is a Secret Hamiltonian in the White House
description: America needs a strong industrial strategy to support its long-term security.
content: President Biden has been called a lot of things, but Hamiltonian is not usually one of them. In spite of his economic successes, hardly anyone has thought to compare the president to the architect of the American economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: On Oscars Carpet, Red Pins Worn to Call for Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: Billie Eilish, Mark Ruffalo, Ava DuVernay and others wore the bright red circles designed and distributed by Artists4Ceasefire.
content: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wehner
title: If There’s One Thing Trump Is Right About, It’s Republicans
description: For the thousandth time, the G.O.P. refused an off-ramp that would free itself from him.
content: For the thousandth time, the Republican Party refused an off-ramp that would free itself from Donald Trump. As long as he’s around, it never will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Wyoming Banned Abortion. She Opened an Abortion Clinic Anyway.
description: The only abortion clinic left in the state has been protested and set on fire, rebuilt and opened as Wyoming grapples with what it means to be conservative in a post-Roe nation.
content: It was not such an implausible idea, back in 2020, when a philanthropist emailed Julie Burkhart to ask if she would consider opening an abortion clinic in Wyoming, one of the nation’s most conservative states and the one that had twice given Donald Trump his biggest margin of victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Jimmy Kimmel Opens with Quips and a Salute to Film Crews
description: The late-night TV host celebrated the blockbuster nominated films and poked fun at many of their stars.
content: On Sunday, Jimmy Kimmel returned to host his fourth Academy Awards, opening with a monologue that riffed on many of last year’s blockbuster movies, particularly “Oppenheimer” and “Barbie,” and poked fun at Hollywood’s biggest stars, including a string of jokes about Robert Downey Jr.’s past drug use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Vilifies Migrants and Mocks Biden’s Stutter in Georgia Speech
description: The former president also attacked Mr. Biden in harsh terms in a combative speech that signaled the beginning of the general election campaign.
content: Early in his remarks in Rome, Ga., at what was effectively his first campaign rally of the general election, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday blasted President Biden’s State of the Union address as an “angry, dark, hate-filled rant” that was more divisive than unifying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamodi Waravita and Mujib Mashal
title: Will Memes About Politicians Now Get Sri Lankans Thrown in Jail?
description: A sweeping new law on online speech threatens the political humor that has helped the island nation get through tough stretches.
content: Even in the darkest of times, Sri Lankans held on to their humor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Virginia Bans Legacy Admissions in Public Universities and Colleges
description: The new law comes as the practice of giving preferential treatment to applicants with family ties to alumni has come under renewed scrutiny.
content: Virginia will end legacy admissions at public universities after Gov. Glenn Youngkin signed a bill on Friday banning the practice that gives applicants with family ties to alumni a boost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: A.I. Is Learning What It Means to Be Alive
description: Given troves of data about genes and cells, A.I. models have made some surprising discoveries. What could they teach us someday?
content: In 1889, a French doctor named Francois-Gilbert Viault climbed down from a mountain in the Andes, drew blood from his arm and inspected it under a microscope. Dr. Viault’s red blood cells, which ferry oxygen, had surged 42 percent. He had discovered a mysterious power of the human body: When it needs more of these crucial cells, it can make them on demand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Robert Chiarito and Alessandro Marazzi Sassoon
title: Who Needs Paper? Many Students Embrace the All-Digital SAT.
description: Several test takers across the country found themselves in favor of the new format of the college admissions exam — even with some technical glitches.
content: The Scantron bubbles were gone. So were the page-long passages and the pressure to speed-read them. No. 2 pencils? Optional, and only for taking notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Cabbage Is Having a Moment
description: How a workhorse vegetable became a darling of the culinary world.
content: In a world in which it’s hard for a vegetable to get a break, cabbage is winning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Greenberg
title: Gabriel García Márquez’s Last Book Is an Unsatisfying Goodbye
description: “Until August” is a “rediscovered” novel that the Colombian master wrote as his memory began failing.
content: Billed as a “rediscovered” novel, “Until August” is likely to be the last published book of fiction by the Colombian master and Nobel laureate Gabriel García Márquez. It would be hard to imagine a more unsatisfying goodbye from the author of “One Hundred Years of Solitude” (1967), the book that threw open the doors of Latin American literature with no less force than Boccaccio’s “Decameron” did for 14th-century Italy. “Until August,” nimbly translated by Anne McLean, is a microscopic story, its contents hardly sufficient for it to be called a novella, much less a finished novel. Reading it may provoke unhealthy levels of frustration in those familiar with García Márquez’s most indelible creations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Ufberg
title: A Book Celebrates James Foley and Confronts a Man Involved in His Murder
description: Colum McCann and Diane Foley, James’s mother, came together to question one of his kidnappers and write a book that delves into the lives of both men.
content: Among the scattered notes taped to the door of the Irish author Colum McCann’s home office in Manhattan is a photograph of James Foley, the American journalist who was murdered by members of the Islamic State in August 2014. In the picture, he leans against a barricade of sandbags in jeans and a flak vest, reading McCann’s novel “Let the Great World Spin.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Vanessa Hudgens reveals her pregnancy on the red carpet.
description: The star said she had “a lot to be excited for” during ABC’s Oscars pre-show.
content: The actress Vanessa Hudgens, one of the hosts of ABC’s Oscars pre-show, included a subtle pregnancy announcement in her coverage of the red carpet on Sunday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Expresses Regret for Calling an Undocumented Immigrant ‘an Illegal’
description: The president had used the word in an unscripted exchange with Republicans during his State of the Union address on Thursday.
content: President Biden expressed regret on Saturday for using the word “illegal” to describe an undocumented immigrant who has been charged in the killing of a 22-year-old nursing student in Georgia, agreeing with his progressive critics that it was an inappropriate term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: One Year After Bank Crisis, a Struggle Over What Needs to Change
description: Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse last March set the stage for a clash between bankers and their regulators.
content: A year ago, the government and America’s largest banks joined forces in a rare moment of comity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California’s Ballot Measure on Mental Health Care Still Isn’t Decided. Why?
description: Proposition 1 was expected to be widely approved, but the vote is close. Here’s what the measure is and what’s at stake.
content: California has about 12 percent of the nation’s population but more than a quarter of America’s homeless people — 181,000-plus at last count.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Palace Releases Photo of Catherine, Two Months After Her Surgery
description: Amid rampant rumors on social media about the condition of the princess, Kensington Palace issued the picture to mark Mother’s Day in Britain. But questions were later raised about the photo.
content: Update: Questions have been raised about a photo released by Kensington Palace.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listening to the Homeless in America
description: Responses to a special Sunday Opinion feature. Also: The rewards of being a chef; atoning for past horrors.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Portugal’s Socialist Party Concedes Election Amid Far-Right Surge
description: A center-right coalition claimed a narrow victory over the governing Socialists, while the populist Chega party soared to a strong third-place finish.
content: Portugal’s Socialist Party conceded defeat on Sunday night in a very tight national election that ended the party’s eight years in power and reflected the country’s drift to the right, which follows a broader trend in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 11, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Watched Her Descend the Stairs Into the Station Carefully’
description: Lost in Brooklyn, two easily identified flying objects and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth G. Dunn
title: He’s Not Just Looking to Make a Quick Billion
description: Marc Lore, the entrepreneur behind Diapers.com and Jet.com, would like to disrupt food delivery. But he really wants to build a brand that actually lasts.
content: When Marc Lore, the e-commerce billionaire, left his position as the chief executive of Walmart.com in 2021, he began to dabble in a variety of long-odds attempts to change the world. He backed a nuclear fusion start-up, and another designing flying taxis. Frustrated with the current state of capitalism, he embarked on plans to build, from scratch, a Bjarke Ingels-designed city of five million in the American West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Here Are the 2024 Oscars Host, Presenters and Performers
description: Jimmy Kimmel will return as the host. Here’s who else you can expect to see tonight.
content: You may have heard that “Oppenheimer,” with a pack-leading 13 nominations, is a lock to win best picture. This is accurate. But even if we’re certain how the night will end, the getting there is the fun part. Here’s what to expect:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: Oscars Red Carpet 2024: See the Stars’ Arrival Looks
description: Ryan Gosling, Margot Robbie, Ariana Grande and other nominees, presenters and performers made their entrances for the 96th Academy Awards in season-defining style.
content: For Oscar hopefuls, awards season can be a long road. With so many appearances, you can’t swing for the fence every time: The occasional bunt is inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muktita Suhartono and Yan Zhuang
title: Indonesia Investigates How Two Pilots Dozed Off During a Flight
description: The incident, which caused the plane carrying 153 people to veer off course before landing safely, added to the country’s troubling aviation safety record.
content: Indonesia’s aviation authority said it would review how the country’s airlines operate night flights after both pilots on a Batik Air flight carrying 153 passengers fell asleep, causing the plane to briefly veer off course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Xi Sticks to His Vision for China’s Rise Even as Growth Slows
description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, believes his vision for technological dominance will keep powering the country’s ascent while the West recedes.
content: Even with growth faltering in China, Xi Jinping appears imperiously assured that he possesses the right road map to surpass Western rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Da’Vine Joy Randolph Wins Best Supporting Actress, Her First Oscar
description: Randolph, who was favored to win, was honored for her turn as a warm, witty cafeteria matriarch in “The Holdovers.”
content: Da’Vine Joy Randolph won the Oscar for best supporting actress for her portrayal in “The Holdovers” of a warm, witty cafeteria matriarch grappling with how to endure the holiday season at a boarding school after the loss of her son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: Biden Clashes With Netanyahu
description: The leaders of the U.S. and Israel are engaged in an increasingly public dispute over Gaza.
content: The leaders of the U.S. and Israel are engaged in an increasingly public dispute over Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Military Enters a New Phase With Gaza Aid Operations
description: As the United States continues providing Israel with munitions, the Pentagon will deliver food and other assistance to Gazans by sea and air.
content: The United States has a history of using its military to get food, water and other humanitarian relief to civilians during wars or natural disasters. The walls of the Pentagon are decorated with photographs of such operations in Haiti, Liberia, Indonesia and countless other countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: After Woman Loses Feet in Subway Shoving, Her Boyfriend Is Charged
description: Christian Valdez was charged with attempted murder after the police said he pushed his girlfriend onto the tracks at Fulton Street station.
content: A woman was struck by a subway train in Manhattan and had both feet amputated after her boyfriend shoved her onto the tracks during a dispute, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Why Haley Voters Should Support Biden
description: The MAGA break with Reagan Republicans is so severe that they should ally with Democrats against Trump.
content: Last Wednesday, a day before he delivered a rousing State of the Union address, Joe Biden issued an invitation to the roughly 30 percent of Republican primary voters who had voted for Nikki Haley in the G.O.P. presidential primaries before she dropped out. The message was simple: Donald Trump doesn’t want you, but we do. After all, Trump said on Truth Social that anyone who made a “contribution” to Haley would be “permanently barred from the MAGA camp.” Biden, by contrast, acknowledged differences of opinion with Haley voters but argued that agreement on democracy, decency, the rule of law and support for NATO should unite Haley voters against Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Morino and Matt Stevens
title: Some Oscar Attendees Delayed by Protesters Calling for Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: Demonstrators near the Dolby Theater chanted “Long live Palestine” while marching down Sunset Boulevard.
content: Some Oscar attendees were delayed arriving at the Dolby Theater on Sunday when demonstrators calling for a cease-fire in Gaza filled lanes of traffic a few blocks south of the theater, according to the Los Angeles police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Kari Lake Tries a New Tactic: Mending Fences
description: The close Trump ally is courting former foes and trying to mend fences as she runs for Senate in Arizona. But bad blood from her 2022 campaign simmers at home.
content: Conciliatory messages on social media. Open invitations for coffee. Zoom calls inviting attendees to unload.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Your Grilled Cheese Needs Toum
description: Just as your leeks need miso, and as your barley soup could use some kielbasa.
content: Good morning. I’m embracing nostalgia today, luxuriating in memories of a Brooklyn I never experienced, even though I’m borough-raised. Imagine egg creams at the soda fountain, a long trip on the rattan seats of an old-timey subway car, then the mechanical horse races at Coney Island and a visit to Ebinger’s afterward, for blackout cake. See me in my peaky newsboy hat!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek and Ameera Harouda
title: Thousands of pregnant women in Gaza suffer from malnutrition, health authorities say.
description: The U.N. has warned that famine is looming in the enclave, and an obstetrician there said that pregnant women face particularly high risks of malnourishment.
content: When Wafaa al-Kurd was nearly due to give birth, she said, she weighed less than she did before becoming pregnant and was surviving on rice and artificial juice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Feathers Fly When Visiting This ‘Henhouse’
description: A brief volume of Elspeth Barker’s writings shows off the late novelist’s ability to soothe, shock and find the humor in dark moments.
content: If you took to your bed after the death of Flaco, the photogenic Eurasian eagle-owl who escaped the Central Park Zoo and enjoyed a year of freedom and celebrity before slamming into 267 West 89th Street (I think he was aiming for the Eldorado), do not under any circumstances pick up the work of Elspeth Barker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden’s Armageddon Moment: When Nuclear Detonation Seemed Possible in Ukraine
description: For a few weeks in October 2022, the White House was consumed in a crisis whose depths were not publicly acknowledged at the time. It was a glimpse of what seemed like a terrifying new era.
content: President Biden was standing in an Upper East Side townhouse owned by the businessman James Murdoch, the rebellious scion of the media empire, surrounded by liberal New York Democrats who had paid handsomely to come hear optimistic talk about the Biden agenda for the next few years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: As a Doctor, I Don’t Fear Covid as I Once Did. But I Carry Its Grave Lessons Forward.
description: Covid is now a permanent part of our lives. Are we finally ready to accept that?
content: Walking through the intensive care unit is often a lesson in how much there is to fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: What David Marchese Learned Talking to the World’s Most Interesting People
description: Actors are different from musicians, Lou Reed is serious about salad, and other tidbits from our great Talk columnist at the end of his run.
content: Actors are different from musicians, Lou Reed is serious about salad, and other tidbits from our great Talk columnist at the end of his run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Jeremy Strong Isn’t Sure He Knows Who He Is
description: After “Succession,” says the actor, “I felt a profound sense of, Was this the event of my life?”
content: After “Succession,” says the actor, “I felt a profound sense of, Was this the event of my life?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold, Gabriel Blanco, James Surdam and Rebecca Suner
title: Behind Our Reporting
description: After making billions in tax-deductible donations to his philanthropy, Elon Musk gave away far less than required in some years — and what he did give often supported his own interests.
content: After making billions in tax-deductible donations to his philanthropy, Elon Musk gave away far less than required in some years — and what he did give often supported his own interests.
source.name: The New York Times
